mybatis.title: MyBatis
mybatis.description: Performs a query, poll, insert, update or delete in a relational database using MyBatis.

statement.description: The statement name in the MyBatis XML mapping file which maps to the query, insert, update or delete operation you wish to evaluate.
statement.title: Statement

maxMessagesPerPoll.description: This option is intended to split results returned by the database pool into the batches and deliver them in multiple exchanges. This integer defines the maximum messages to deliver in single exchange. By default, no maximum is set. Can be used to set a limit of e.g. 1000 to avoid when starting up the server that there are thousands of files. Set a value of 0 or negative to disable it.
maxMessagesPerPoll.title: Max Messages Per Poll

onConsume.description: Statement to run after data has been processed in the route
onConsume.title: On Consume

routeEmptyResultSet.description: Whether allow empty resultset to be routed to the next hop
routeEmptyResultSet.title: Route Empty Result Set

sendEmptyMessageWhenIdle.description: If the polling consumer did not poll any files, you can enable this option to send an empty message (no body) instead.
sendEmptyMessageWhenIdle.title: Send Empty Message When Idle

transacted.description: Enables or disables transaction. If enabled then if processing an exchange failed then the consumer breaks out processing any further exchanges to cause a rollback eager.
transacted.title: Transacted

useIterator.description: Process resultset individually or as a list
useIterator.title: Use Iterator

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

pollStrategy.description: A pluggable org.apache.camel.PollingConsumerPollingStrategy allowing you to provide your custom implementation to control error handling usually occurred during the poll operation before an Exchange have been created and being routed in Camel.
pollStrategy.title: Poll Strategy

executorType.description: The executor type to be used while executing statements. simple - executor does nothing special. reuse - executor reuses prepared statements. batch - executor reuses statements and batches updates.
executorType.title: Executor Type

inputHeader.description: User the header value for input parameters instead of the message body. By default, inputHeader == null and the input parameters are taken from the message body. If outputHeader is set, the value is used and query parameters will be taken from the header instead of the body.
inputHeader.title: Input Header

outputHeader.description: Store the query result in a header instead of the message body. By default, outputHeader == null and the query result is stored in the message body, any existing content in the message body is discarded. If outputHeader is set, the value is used as the name of the header to store the query result and the original message body is preserved. Setting outputHeader will also omit populating the default CamelMyBatisResult header since it would be the same as outputHeader all the time.
outputHeader.title: Output Header

statementType.description: Mandatory to specify for the producer to control which kind of operation to invoke.
statementType.title: Statement Type

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

backoffErrorThreshold.description: The number of subsequent error polls (failed due some error) that should happen before the backoffMultipler should kick-in.
backoffErrorThreshold.title: Backoff Error Threshold

backoffIdleThreshold.description: The number of subsequent idle polls that should happen before the backoffMultipler should kick-in.
backoffIdleThreshold.title: Backoff Idle Threshold

backoffMultiplier.description: To let the scheduled polling consumer backoff if there has been a number of subsequent idles/errors in a row. The multiplier is then the number of polls that will be skipped before the next actual attempt is happening again. When this option is in use then backoffIdleThreshold and/or backoffErrorThreshold must also be configured.
backoffMultiplier.title: Backoff Multiplier

greedy.description: If greedy is enabled, then the ScheduledPollConsumer will run immediately again, if the previous run polled 1 or more messages.
greedy.title: Greedy

initialDelay.description: Milliseconds before the first poll starts.
initialDelay.title: Initial Delay

repeatCount.description: Specifies a maximum limit of number of fires. So if you set it to 1, the scheduler will only fire once. If you set it to 5, it will only fire five times. A value of zero or negative means fire forever.
repeatCount.title: Repeat Count

runLoggingLevel.description: The consumer logs a start/complete log line when it polls. This option allows you to configure the logging level for that.
runLoggingLevel.title: Run Logging Level

scheduledExecutorService.description: Allows for configuring a custom/shared thread pool to use for the consumer. By default each consumer has its own single threaded thread pool.
scheduledExecutorService.title: Scheduled Executor Service

scheduler.description: To use a cron scheduler from either camel-spring or camel-quartz component. Use value spring or quartz for built in scheduler
scheduler.title: Scheduler

schedulerProperties.description: To configure additional properties when using a custom scheduler or any of the Quartz, Spring based scheduler.
schedulerProperties.title: Scheduler Properties

startScheduler.description: Whether the scheduler should be auto started.
startScheduler.title: Start Scheduler

timeUnit.description: Time unit for initialDelay and delay options.
timeUnit.title: Time Unit

useFixedDelay.description: Controls if fixed delay or fixed rate is used. See ScheduledExecutorService in JDK for details.
useFixedDelay.title: Use Fixed Delay

mybatis-bean.title: MyBatis Bean
mybatis-bean.description: Perform queries, inserts, updates or deletes in a relational database using MyBatis.

beanName.description: Name of the bean with the MyBatis annotations. This can either by a type alias or a FQN class name.
beanName.title: Bean Name

methodName.description: Name of the method on the bean that has the SQL query to be executed.
methodName.title: Method Name

executorType.description: The executor type to be used while executing statements. simple - executor does nothing special. reuse - executor reuses prepared statements. batch - executor reuses statements and batches updates.
executorType.title: Executor Type

inputHeader.description: User the header value for input parameters instead of the message body. By default, inputHeader == null and the input parameters are taken from the message body. If outputHeader is set, the value is used and query parameters will be taken from the header instead of the body.
inputHeader.title: Input Header

outputHeader.description: Store the query result in a header instead of the message body. By default, outputHeader == null and the query result is stored in the message body, any existing content in the message body is discarded. If outputHeader is set, the value is used as the name of the header to store the query result and the original message body is preserved. Setting outputHeader will also omit populating the default CamelMyBatisResult header since it would be the same as outputHeader all the time.
outputHeader.title: Output Header

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

nats.title: Nats
nats.description: Send and receive messages from NATS messaging system.

topic.description: The name of topic we want to use
topic.title: Topic

connectionTimeout.description: Timeout for connection attempts. (in milliseconds)
connectionTimeout.title: Connection Timeout

flushConnection.description: Define if we want to flush connection when stopping or not
flushConnection.title: Flush Connection

maxPingsOut.description: maximum number of pings have not received a response allowed by the client
maxPingsOut.title: Max Pings Out

noEcho.description: Turn off echo. If supported by the gnatsd version you are connecting to this flag will prevent the server from echoing messages back to the connection if it has subscriptions on the subject being published to.
noEcho.title: No Echo

noRandomizeServers.description: Whether or not randomizing the order of servers for the connection attempts
noRandomizeServers.title: No Randomize Servers

pedantic.description: Whether or not running in pedantic mode (this affects performance)
pedantic.title: Pedantic

pingInterval.description: Ping interval to be aware if connection is still alive (in milliseconds)
pingInterval.title: Ping Interval

reconnect.description: Whether or not using reconnection feature
reconnect.title: Reconnect

reconnectTimeWait.description: Waiting time before attempts reconnection (in milliseconds)
reconnectTimeWait.title: Reconnect Time Wait

requestCleanupInterval.description: Interval to clean up cancelled/timed out requests.
requestCleanupInterval.title: Request Cleanup Interval

servers.description: URLs to one or more NAT servers. Use comma to separate URLs when specifying multiple servers.
servers.title: Servers

verbose.description: Whether or not running in verbose mode
verbose.title: Verbose

maxMessages.description: Stop receiving messages from a topic we are subscribing to after maxMessages
maxMessages.title: Max Messages

queueName.description: The Queue name if we are using nats for a queue configuration
queueName.title: Queue Name

replyToDisabled.description: Can be used to turn off sending back reply message in the consumer.
replyToDisabled.title: Reply To Disabled

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

replySubject.description: the subject to which subscribers should send response
replySubject.title: Reply Subject

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

connection.description: Reference an already instantiated connection to Nats server
connection.title: Connection

headerFilterStrategy.description: Define the header filtering strategy
headerFilterStrategy.title: Header Filter Strategy

traceConnection.description: Whether or not connection trace messages should be printed to standard out for fine grained debugging of connection issues.
traceConnection.title: Trace Connection

secure.description: Set secure option indicating TLS is required
secure.title: Secure

netty.title: Netty
netty.description: Socket level networking using TCP or UDP with Netty 4.x.

protocol.description: The protocol to use which can be tcp or udp.
protocol.title: Protocol

host.description: The hostname. For the consumer the hostname is localhost or 0.0.0.0. For the producer the hostname is the remote host to connect to
host.title: Host

port.description: The host port number
port.title: Port

disconnect.description: Whether or not to disconnect(close) from Netty Channel right after use. Can be used for both consumer and producer.
disconnect.title: Disconnect

keepAlive.description: Setting to ensure socket is not closed due to inactivity
keepAlive.title: Keep Alive

reuseChannel.description: This option allows producers and consumers (in client mode) to reuse the same Netty Channel for the lifecycle of processing the Exchange. This is useful if you need to call a server multiple times in a Camel route and want to use the same network connection. When using this, the channel is not returned to the connection pool until the Exchange is done; or disconnected if the disconnect option is set to true. The reused Channel is stored on the Exchange as an exchange property with the key NettyConstants#NETTY_CHANNEL which allows you to obtain the channel during routing and use it as well.
reuseChannel.title: Reuse Channel

sync.description: Setting to set endpoint as one-way or request-response
sync.title: Sync

tcpNoDelay.description: Setting to improve TCP protocol performance
tcpNoDelay.title: Tcp No Delay

broadcast.description: Setting to choose Multicast over UDP
broadcast.title: Broadcast

clientMode.description: If the clientMode is true, netty consumer will connect the address as a TCP client.
clientMode.title: Client Mode

reconnect.description: Used only in clientMode in consumer, the consumer will attempt to reconnect on disconnection if this is enabled
reconnect.title: Reconnect

reconnectInterval.description: Used if reconnect and clientMode is enabled. The interval in milli seconds to attempt reconnection
reconnectInterval.title: Reconnect Interval

backlog.description: Allows to configure a backlog for netty consumer (server). Note the backlog is just a best effort depending on the OS. Setting this option to a value such as 200, 500 or 1000, tells the TCP stack how long the accept queue can be If this option is not configured, then the backlog depends on OS setting.
backlog.title: Backlog

bossCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default bossCount parameter from Netty, which is 1. User can use this option to override the default bossCount from Netty
bossCount.title: Boss Count

bossGroup.description: Set the BossGroup which could be used for handling the new connection of the server side across the NettyEndpoint
bossGroup.title: Boss Group

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

disconnectOnNoReply.description: If sync is enabled then this option dictates NettyConsumer if it should disconnect where there is no reply to send back.
disconnectOnNoReply.title: Disconnect On No Reply

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

networkInterface.description: When using UDP then this option can be used to specify a network interface by its name, such as eth0 to join a multicast group.
networkInterface.title: Network Interface

noReplyLogLevel.description: If sync is enabled this option dictates NettyConsumer which logging level to use when logging a there is no reply to send back.
noReplyLogLevel.title: No Reply Log Level

serverClosedChannelExceptionCaughtLogLev.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an java.nio.channels.ClosedChannelException then its logged using this logging level. This is used to avoid logging the closed channel exceptions, as clients can disconnect abruptly and then cause a flood of closed exceptions in the Netty server.
serverClosedChannelExceptionCaughtLogLev.title: Server Closed Channel Exception Caught Log Level

serverExceptionCaughtLogLevel.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an exception then its logged using this logging level.
serverExceptionCaughtLogLevel.title: Server Exception Caught Log Level

usingExecutorService.description: Whether to use ordered thread pool, to ensure events are processed orderly on the same channel.
usingExecutorService.title: Using Executor Service

connectTimeout.description: Time to wait for a socket connection to be available. Value is in milliseconds.
connectTimeout.title: Connect Timeout

requestTimeout.description: Allows to use a timeout for the Netty producer when calling a remote server. By default no timeout is in use. The value is in milli seconds, so eg 30000 is 30 seconds. The requestTimeout is using Netty's ReadTimeoutHandler to trigger the timeout.
requestTimeout.title: Request Timeout

correlationManager.description: To use a custom correlation manager to manage how request and reply messages are mapped when using request/reply with the netty producer. This should only be used if you have a way to map requests together with replies such as if there is correlation ids in both the request and reply messages. This can be used if you want to multiplex concurrent messages on the same channel (aka connection) in netty. When doing this you must have a way to correlate the request and reply messages so you can store the right reply on the inflight Camel Exchange before its continued routed. We recommend extending the TimeoutCorrelationManagerSupport when you build custom correlation managers. This provides support for timeout and other complexities you otherwise would need to implement as well. See also the producerPoolEnabled option for more details.
correlationManager.title: Correlation Manager

lazyChannelCreation.description: Channels can be lazily created to avoid exceptions, if the remote server is not up and running when the Camel producer is started.
lazyChannelCreation.title: Lazy Channel Creation

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

producerPoolEnabled.description: Whether producer pool is enabled or not. Important: If you turn this off then a single shared connection is used for the producer, also if you are doing request/reply. That means there is a potential issue with interleaved responses if replies comes back out-of-order. Therefore you need to have a correlation id in both the request and reply messages so you can properly correlate the replies to the Camel callback that is responsible for continue processing the message in Camel. To do this you need to implement NettyCamelStateCorrelationManager as correlation manager and configure it via the correlationManager option. See also the correlationManager option for more details.
producerPoolEnabled.title: Producer Pool Enabled

producerPoolMaxIdle.description: Sets the cap on the number of idle instances in the pool.
producerPoolMaxIdle.title: Producer Pool Max Idle

producerPoolMaxTotal.description: Sets the cap on the number of objects that can be allocated by the pool (checked out to clients, or idle awaiting checkout) at a given time. Use a negative value for no limit.
producerPoolMaxTotal.title: Producer Pool Max Total

producerPoolMinEvictableIdle.description: Sets the minimum amount of time (value in millis) an object may sit idle in the pool before it is eligible for eviction by the idle object evictor.
producerPoolMinEvictableIdle.title: Producer Pool Min Evictable Idle

producerPoolMinIdle.description: Sets the minimum number of instances allowed in the producer pool before the evictor thread (if active) spawns new objects.
producerPoolMinIdle.title: Producer Pool Min Idle

udpConnectionlessSending.description: This option supports connection less udp sending which is a real fire and forget. A connected udp send receive the PortUnreachableException if no one is listen on the receiving port.
udpConnectionlessSending.title: Udp Connectionless Sending

useByteBuf.description: If the useByteBuf is true, netty producer will turn the message body into ByteBuf before sending it out.
useByteBuf.title: Use Byte Buf

hostnameVerification.description: To enable/disable hostname verification on SSLEngine
hostnameVerification.title: Hostname Verification

allowSerializedHeaders.description: Only used for TCP when transferExchange is true. When set to true, serializable objects in headers and properties will be added to the exchange. Otherwise Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.
allowSerializedHeaders.title: Allow Serialized Headers

nativeTransport.description: Whether to use native transport instead of NIO. Native transport takes advantage of the host operating system and is only supported on some platforms. You need to add the netty JAR for the host operating system you are using. See more details at: http://netty.io/wiki/native-transports.html
nativeTransport.title: Native Transport

options.description: Allows to configure additional netty options using option. as prefix. For example option.child.keepAlive=false to set the netty option child.keepAlive=false. See the Netty documentation for possible options that can be used.
options.title: Options

receiveBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during inbound communication. Size is bytes.
receiveBufferSize.title: Receive Buffer Size

receiveBufferSizePredictor.description: Configures the buffer size predictor. See details at Jetty documentation and this mail thread.
receiveBufferSizePredictor.title: Receive Buffer Size Predictor

sendBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during outbound communication. Size is bytes.
sendBufferSize.title: Send Buffer Size

synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used
synchronous.title: Synchronous

transferExchange.description: Only used for TCP. You can transfer the exchange over the wire instead of just the body. The following fields are transferred: In body, Out body, fault body, In headers, Out headers, fault headers, exchange properties, exchange exception. This requires that the objects are serializable. Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.
transferExchange.title: Transfer Exchange

udpByteArrayCodec.description: For UDP only. If enabled the using byte array codec instead of Java serialization protocol.
udpByteArrayCodec.title: Udp Byte Array Codec

workerCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default workerCount parameter from Netty (which is cpu_core_threads x 2). User can use this option to override the default workerCount from Netty.
workerCount.title: Worker Count

workerGroup.description: To use a explicit EventLoopGroup as the boss thread pool. For example to share a thread pool with multiple consumers or producers. By default each consumer or producer has their own worker pool with 2 x cpu count core threads.
workerGroup.title: Worker Group

allowDefaultCodec.description: The netty component installs a default codec if both, encoder/decoder is null and textline is false. Setting allowDefaultCodec to false prevents the netty component from installing a default codec as the first element in the filter chain.
allowDefaultCodec.title: Allow Default Codec

autoAppendDelimiter.description: Whether or not to auto append missing end delimiter when sending using the textline codec.
autoAppendDelimiter.title: Auto Append Delimiter

decoderMaxLineLength.description: The max line length to use for the textline codec.
decoderMaxLineLength.title: Decoder Max Line Length

decoders.description: A list of decoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.
decoders.title: Decoders

delimiter.description: The delimiter to use for the textline codec. Possible values are LINE and NULL.
delimiter.title: Delimiter

encoders.description: A list of encoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.
encoders.title: Encoders

encoding.description: The encoding (a charset name) to use for the textline codec. If not provided, Camel will use the JVM default Charset.
encoding.title: Encoding

textline.description: Only used for TCP. If no codec is specified, you can use this flag to indicate a text line based codec; if not specified or the value is false, then Object Serialization is assumed over TCP - however only Strings are allowed to be serialized by default.
textline.title: Textline

enabledProtocols.description: Which protocols to enable when using SSL
enabledProtocols.title: Enabled Protocols

keyStoreFile.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption
keyStoreFile.title: Key Store File

keyStoreFormat.description: Keystore format to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to JKS if not set
keyStoreFormat.title: Key Store Format

keyStoreResource.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.
keyStoreResource.title: Key Store Resource

needClientAuth.description: Configures whether the server needs client authentication when using SSL.
needClientAuth.title: Need Client Auth

passphrase.description: Password setting to use in order to encrypt/decrypt payloads sent using SSH
passphrase.title: Passphrase

securityProvider.description: Security provider to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to SunX509 if not set.
securityProvider.title: Security Provider

ssl.description: Setting to specify whether SSL encryption is applied to this endpoint
ssl.title: Ssl

sslClientCertHeaders.description: When enabled and in SSL mode, then the Netty consumer will enrich the Camel Message with headers having information about the client certificate such as subject name, issuer name, serial number, and the valid date range.
sslClientCertHeaders.title: Ssl Client Cert Headers

sslHandler.description: Reference to a class that could be used to return an SSL Handler
sslHandler.title: Ssl Handler

trustStoreFile.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption
trustStoreFile.title: Trust Store File

trustStoreResource.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.
trustStoreResource.title: Trust Store Resource

netty-http.title: Netty HTTP
netty-http.description: Netty HTTP server and client using the Netty 4.x.

protocol.description: The protocol to use which is either http, https or proxy - a consumer only option.
protocol.title: Protocol

host.description: The local hostname such as localhost, or 0.0.0.0 when being a consumer. The remote HTTP server hostname when using producer.
host.title: Host

port.description: The host port number
port.title: Port

bridgeEndpoint.description: If the option is true, the producer will ignore the NettyHttpConstants.HTTP_URI header, and use the endpoint's URI for request. You may also set the throwExceptionOnFailure to be false to let the producer send all the fault response back. The consumer working in the bridge mode will skip the gzip compression and WWW URL form encoding (by adding the Exchange.SKIP_GZIP_ENCODING and Exchange.SKIP_WWW_FORM_URLENCODED headers to the consumed exchange).
bridgeEndpoint.title: Bridge Endpoint

disconnect.description: Whether or not to disconnect(close) from Netty Channel right after use. Can be used for both consumer and producer.
disconnect.title: Disconnect

keepAlive.description: Setting to ensure socket is not closed due to inactivity
keepAlive.title: Keep Alive

reuseChannel.description: This option allows producers and consumers (in client mode) to reuse the same Netty Channel for the lifecycle of processing the Exchange. This is useful if you need to call a server multiple times in a Camel route and want to use the same network connection. When using this, the channel is not returned to the connection pool until the Exchange is done; or disconnected if the disconnect option is set to true. The reused Channel is stored on the Exchange as an exchange property with the key NettyConstants#NETTY_CHANNEL which allows you to obtain the channel during routing and use it as well.
reuseChannel.title: Reuse Channel

sync.description: Setting to set endpoint as one-way or request-response
sync.title: Sync

tcpNoDelay.description: Setting to improve TCP protocol performance
tcpNoDelay.title: Tcp No Delay

matchOnUriPrefix.description: Whether or not Camel should try to find a target consumer by matching the URI prefix if no exact match is found.
matchOnUriPrefix.title: Match On Uri Prefix

muteException.description: If enabled and an Exchange failed processing on the consumer side the response's body won't contain the exception's stack trace.
muteException.title: Mute Exception

send503whenSuspended.description: Whether to send back HTTP status code 503 when the consumer has been suspended. If the option is false then the Netty Acceptor is unbound when the consumer is suspended, so clients cannot connect anymore.
send503whenSuspended.title: Send503when Suspended

backlog.description: Allows to configure a backlog for netty consumer (server). Note the backlog is just a best effort depending on the OS. Setting this option to a value such as 200, 500 or 1000, tells the TCP stack how long the accept queue can be If this option is not configured, then the backlog depends on OS setting.
backlog.title: Backlog

bossCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default bossCount parameter from Netty, which is 1. User can use this option to override the default bossCount from Netty
bossCount.title: Boss Count

bossGroup.description: Set the BossGroup which could be used for handling the new connection of the server side across the NettyEndpoint
bossGroup.title: Boss Group

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

chunkedMaxContentLength.description: Value in bytes the max content length per chunked frame received on the Netty HTTP server.
chunkedMaxContentLength.title: Chunked Max Content Length

compression.description: Allow using gzip/deflate for compression on the Netty HTTP server if the client supports it from the HTTP headers.
compression.title: Compression

disconnectOnNoReply.description: If sync is enabled then this option dictates NettyConsumer if it should disconnect where there is no reply to send back.
disconnectOnNoReply.title: Disconnect On No Reply

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

httpMethodRestrict.description: To disable HTTP methods on the Netty HTTP consumer. You can specify multiple separated by comma.
httpMethodRestrict.title: Http Method Restrict

logWarnOnBadRequest.description: Whether Netty HTTP server should log a WARN if decoding the HTTP request failed and a HTTP Status 400 (bad request) is returned.
logWarnOnBadRequest.title: Log Warn On Bad Request

mapHeaders.description: If this option is enabled, then during binding from Netty to Camel Message then the headers will be mapped as well (eg added as header to the Camel Message as well). You can turn off this option to disable this. The headers can still be accessed from the org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpMessage message with the method getHttpRequest() that returns the Netty HTTP request io.netty.handler.codec.http.HttpRequest instance.
mapHeaders.title: Map Headers

maxChunkSize.description: The maximum length of the content or each chunk. If the content length (or the length of each chunk) exceeds this value, the content or chunk will be split into multiple io.netty.handler.codec.http.HttpContents whose length is maxChunkSize at maximum. See io.netty.handler.codec.http.HttpObjectDecoder
maxChunkSize.title: Max Chunk Size

maxHeaderSize.description: The maximum length of all headers. If the sum of the length of each header exceeds this value, a io.netty.handler.codec.TooLongFrameException will be raised.
maxHeaderSize.title: Max Header Size

maxInitialLineLength.description: The maximum length of the initial line (e.g. {code GET / HTTP/1.0} or {code HTTP/1.0 200 OK}) If the length of the initial line exceeds this value, a TooLongFrameException will be raised. See io.netty.handler.codec.http.HttpObjectDecoder
maxInitialLineLength.title: Max Initial Line Length

nettySharedHttpServer.description: To use a shared Netty HTTP server. See Netty HTTP Server Example for more details.
nettySharedHttpServer.title: Netty Shared Http Server

noReplyLogLevel.description: If sync is enabled this option dictates NettyConsumer which logging level to use when logging a there is no reply to send back.
noReplyLogLevel.title: No Reply Log Level

serverClosedChannelExceptionCaughtLogLev.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an java.nio.channels.ClosedChannelException then its logged using this logging level. This is used to avoid logging the closed channel exceptions, as clients can disconnect abruptly and then cause a flood of closed exceptions in the Netty server.
serverClosedChannelExceptionCaughtLogLev.title: Server Closed Channel Exception Caught Log Level

serverExceptionCaughtLogLevel.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an exception then its logged using this logging level.
serverExceptionCaughtLogLevel.title: Server Exception Caught Log Level

traceEnabled.description: Specifies whether to enable HTTP TRACE for this Netty HTTP consumer. By default TRACE is turned off.
traceEnabled.title: Trace Enabled

urlDecodeHeaders.description: If this option is enabled, then during binding from Netty to Camel Message then the header values will be URL decoded (eg %20 will be a space character. Notice this option is used by the default org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpBinding and therefore if you implement a custom org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpBinding then you would need to decode the headers accordingly to this option.
urlDecodeHeaders.title: Url Decode Headers

usingExecutorService.description: Whether to use ordered thread pool, to ensure events are processed orderly on the same channel.
usingExecutorService.title: Using Executor Service

connectTimeout.description: Time to wait for a socket connection to be available. Value is in milliseconds.
connectTimeout.title: Connect Timeout

cookieHandler.description: Configure a cookie handler to maintain a HTTP session
cookieHandler.title: Cookie Handler

requestTimeout.description: Allows to use a timeout for the Netty producer when calling a remote server. By default no timeout is in use. The value is in milli seconds, so eg 30000 is 30 seconds. The requestTimeout is using Netty's ReadTimeoutHandler to trigger the timeout.
requestTimeout.title: Request Timeout

throwExceptionOnFailure.description: Option to disable throwing the HttpOperationFailedException in case of failed responses from the remote server. This allows you to get all responses regardless of the HTTP status code.
throwExceptionOnFailure.title: Throw Exception On Failure

lazyChannelCreation.description: Channels can be lazily created to avoid exceptions, if the remote server is not up and running when the Camel producer is started.
lazyChannelCreation.title: Lazy Channel Creation

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

okStatusCodeRange.description: The status codes which are considered a success response. The values are inclusive. Multiple ranges can be defined, separated by comma, e.g. 200-204,209,301-304. Each range must be a single number or from-to with the dash included. The default range is 200-299
okStatusCodeRange.title: Ok Status Code Range

producerPoolEnabled.description: Whether producer pool is enabled or not. Important: If you turn this off then a single shared connection is used for the producer, also if you are doing request/reply. That means there is a potential issue with interleaved responses if replies comes back out-of-order. Therefore you need to have a correlation id in both the request and reply messages so you can properly correlate the replies to the Camel callback that is responsible for continue processing the message in Camel. To do this you need to implement NettyCamelStateCorrelationManager as correlation manager and configure it via the correlationManager option. See also the correlationManager option for more details.
producerPoolEnabled.title: Producer Pool Enabled

producerPoolMaxIdle.description: Sets the cap on the number of idle instances in the pool.
producerPoolMaxIdle.title: Producer Pool Max Idle

producerPoolMaxTotal.description: Sets the cap on the number of objects that can be allocated by the pool (checked out to clients, or idle awaiting checkout) at a given time. Use a negative value for no limit.
producerPoolMaxTotal.title: Producer Pool Max Total

producerPoolMinEvictableIdle.description: Sets the minimum amount of time (value in millis) an object may sit idle in the pool before it is eligible for eviction by the idle object evictor.
producerPoolMinEvictableIdle.title: Producer Pool Min Evictable Idle

producerPoolMinIdle.description: Sets the minimum number of instances allowed in the producer pool before the evictor thread (if active) spawns new objects.
producerPoolMinIdle.title: Producer Pool Min Idle

useRelativePath.description: Sets whether to use a relative path in HTTP requests.
useRelativePath.title: Use Relative Path

hostnameVerification.description: To enable/disable hostname verification on SSLEngine
hostnameVerification.title: Hostname Verification

allowSerializedHeaders.description: Only used for TCP when transferExchange is true. When set to true, serializable objects in headers and properties will be added to the exchange. Otherwise Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.
allowSerializedHeaders.title: Allow Serialized Headers

configuration.description: To use a custom configured NettyHttpConfiguration for configuring this endpoint.
configuration.title: Configuration

disableStreamCache.description: Determines whether or not the raw input stream from Netty HttpRequest#getContent() or HttpResponset#getContent() is cached or not (Camel will read the stream into a in light-weight memory based Stream caching) cache. By default Camel will cache the Netty input stream to support reading it multiple times to ensure it Camel can retrieve all data from the stream. However you can set this option to true when you for example need to access the raw stream, such as streaming it directly to a file or other persistent store. Mind that if you enable this option, then you cannot read the Netty stream multiple times out of the box, and you would need manually to reset the reader index on the Netty raw stream. Also Netty will auto-close the Netty stream when the Netty HTTP server/HTTP client is done processing, which means that if the asynchronous routing engine is in use then any asynchronous thread that may continue routing the org.apache.camel.Exchange may not be able to read the Netty stream, because Netty has closed it.
disableStreamCache.title: Disable Stream Cache

headerFilterStrategy.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.spi.HeaderFilterStrategy to filter headers.
headerFilterStrategy.title: Header Filter Strategy

nativeTransport.description: Whether to use native transport instead of NIO. Native transport takes advantage of the host operating system and is only supported on some platforms. You need to add the netty JAR for the host operating system you are using. See more details at: http://netty.io/wiki/native-transports.html
nativeTransport.title: Native Transport

nettyHttpBinding.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpBinding for binding to/from Netty and Camel Message API.
nettyHttpBinding.title: Netty Http Binding

options.description: Allows to configure additional netty options using option. as prefix. For example option.child.keepAlive=false to set the netty option child.keepAlive=false. See the Netty documentation for possible options that can be used.
options.title: Options

receiveBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during inbound communication. Size is bytes.
receiveBufferSize.title: Receive Buffer Size

receiveBufferSizePredictor.description: Configures the buffer size predictor. See details at Jetty documentation and this mail thread.
receiveBufferSizePredictor.title: Receive Buffer Size Predictor

sendBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during outbound communication. Size is bytes.
sendBufferSize.title: Send Buffer Size

synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used
synchronous.title: Synchronous

transferException.description: If enabled and an Exchange failed processing on the consumer side, and if the caused Exception was send back serialized in the response as a application/x-java-serialized-object content type. On the producer side the exception will be deserialized and thrown as is, instead of the HttpOperationFailedException. The caused exception is required to be serialized. This is by default turned off. If you enable this then be aware that Java will deserialize the incoming data from the request to Java and that can be a potential security risk.
transferException.title: Transfer Exception

transferExchange.description: Only used for TCP. You can transfer the exchange over the wire instead of just the body. The following fields are transferred: In body, Out body, fault body, In headers, Out headers, fault headers, exchange properties, exchange exception. This requires that the objects are serializable. Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.
transferExchange.title: Transfer Exchange

workerCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default workerCount parameter from Netty (which is cpu_core_threads x 2). User can use this option to override the default workerCount from Netty.
workerCount.title: Worker Count

workerGroup.description: To use a explicit EventLoopGroup as the boss thread pool. For example to share a thread pool with multiple consumers or producers. By default each consumer or producer has their own worker pool with 2 x cpu count core threads.
workerGroup.title: Worker Group

decoders.description: A list of decoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.
decoders.title: Decoders

encoders.description: A list of encoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.
encoders.title: Encoders

enabledProtocols.description: Which protocols to enable when using SSL
enabledProtocols.title: Enabled Protocols

keyStoreFile.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption
keyStoreFile.title: Key Store File

keyStoreFormat.description: Keystore format to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to JKS if not set
keyStoreFormat.title: Key Store Format

keyStoreResource.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.
keyStoreResource.title: Key Store Resource

needClientAuth.description: Configures whether the server needs client authentication when using SSL.
needClientAuth.title: Need Client Auth

passphrase.description: Password setting to use in order to encrypt/decrypt payloads sent using SSH
passphrase.title: Passphrase

securityConfiguration.description: Refers to a org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpSecurityConfiguration for configuring secure web resources.
securityConfiguration.title: Security Configuration

securityOptions.description: To configure NettyHttpSecurityConfiguration using key/value pairs from the map
securityOptions.title: Security Options

securityProvider.description: Security provider to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to SunX509 if not set.
securityProvider.title: Security Provider

ssl.description: Setting to specify whether SSL encryption is applied to this endpoint
ssl.title: Ssl

sslClientCertHeaders.description: When enabled and in SSL mode, then the Netty consumer will enrich the Camel Message with headers having information about the client certificate such as subject name, issuer name, serial number, and the valid date range.
sslClientCertHeaders.title: Ssl Client Cert Headers

sslHandler.description: Reference to a class that could be used to return an SSL Handler
sslHandler.title: Ssl Handler

trustStoreFile.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption
trustStoreFile.title: Trust Store File

trustStoreResource.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.
trustStoreResource.title: Trust Store Resource

database.description: Path to database file. Will be created if not exists.
database.title: Database

collection.description: Name of Nitrite collection. Cannot be used in combination with repositoryClass option.
collection.title: Collection

repositoryClass.description: Class of Nitrite ObjectRepository. Cannot be used in combination with collection option.
repositoryClass.title: Repository Class

repositoryName.description: Optional name of ObjectRepository. Can be only used in combination with repositoryClass, otherwise have no effect
repositoryName.title: Repository Name

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

password.description: Password for Nitrite database. Required, if option username specified.
password.title: Password

username.description: Username for Nitrite database. Database is not secured if option not specified.
username.title: Username

baseUrl.description: Base URL of the repository to which the request is made through the OAI-PMH protocol
baseUrl.title: Base Url

from.description: Specifies a lower bound for datestamp-based selective harvesting. UTC DateTime value
from.title: From

identifier.description: Identifier of the requested resources. Applicable only with certain verbs
identifier.title: Identifier

metadataPrefix.description: Specifies the metadataPrefix of the format that should be included in the metadata part of the returned records.
metadataPrefix.title: Metadata Prefix

set.description: Specifies membership as a criteria for set-based selective harvesting
set.title: Set

until.description: Specifies an upper bound for datestamp-based selective harvesting. UTC DateTime value.
until.title: Until

verb.description: Request name supported by OAI-PMh protocol
verb.title: Verb

sendEmptyMessageWhenIdle.description: If the polling consumer did not poll any files, you can enable this option to send an empty message (no body) instead.
sendEmptyMessageWhenIdle.title: Send Empty Message When Idle

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

pollStrategy.description: A pluggable org.apache.camel.PollingConsumerPollingStrategy allowing you to provide your custom implementation to control error handling usually occurred during the poll operation before an Exchange have been created and being routed in Camel.
pollStrategy.title: Poll Strategy

onlyFirst.description: Returns the response of a single request. Otherwise it will make requests until there is no more data to return.
onlyFirst.title: Only First

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

backoffErrorThreshold.description: The number of subsequent error polls (failed due some error) that should happen before the backoffMultipler should kick-in.
backoffErrorThreshold.title: Backoff Error Threshold

backoffIdleThreshold.description: The number of subsequent idle polls that should happen before the backoffMultipler should kick-in.
backoffIdleThreshold.title: Backoff Idle Threshold

backoffMultiplier.description: To let the scheduled polling consumer backoff if there has been a number of subsequent idles/errors in a row. The multiplier is then the number of polls that will be skipped before the next actual attempt is happening again. When this option is in use then backoffIdleThreshold and/or backoffErrorThreshold must also be configured.
backoffMultiplier.title: Backoff Multiplier

greedy.description: If greedy is enabled, then the ScheduledPollConsumer will run immediately again, if the previous run polled 1 or more messages.
greedy.title: Greedy

initialDelay.description: Milliseconds before the first poll starts.
initialDelay.title: Initial Delay

repeatCount.description: Specifies a maximum limit of number of fires. So if you set it to 1, the scheduler will only fire once. If you set it to 5, it will only fire five times. A value of zero or negative means fire forever.
repeatCount.title: Repeat Count

runLoggingLevel.description: The consumer logs a start/complete log line when it polls. This option allows you to configure the logging level for that.
runLoggingLevel.title: Run Logging Level

scheduledExecutorService.description: Allows for configuring a custom/shared thread pool to use for the consumer. By default each consumer has its own single threaded thread pool.
scheduledExecutorService.title: Scheduled Executor Service

scheduler.description: To use a cron scheduler from either camel-spring or camel-quartz component. Use value spring or quartz for built in scheduler
scheduler.title: Scheduler

schedulerProperties.description: To configure additional properties when using a custom scheduler or any of the Quartz, Spring based scheduler.
schedulerProperties.title: Scheduler Properties

startScheduler.description: Whether the scheduler should be auto started.
startScheduler.title: Start Scheduler

timeUnit.description: Time unit for initialDelay and delay options.
timeUnit.title: Time Unit

useFixedDelay.description: Controls if fixed delay or fixed rate is used. See ScheduledExecutorService in JDK for details.
useFixedDelay.title: Use Fixed Delay

ssl.description: Causes the defined url to make an https request
ssl.title: Ssl

methodName.description: What sub operation to use for the selected operation
methodName.title: Method Name

connectTimeout.description: HTTP connection creation timeout in milliseconds, defaults to 30,000 (30 seconds)
connectTimeout.title: Connect Timeout

contentType.description: Content-Type header value can be used to specify JSON or XML message format, defaults to application/json;charset=utf-8
contentType.title: Content Type

entityProviderReadProperties.description: Custom entity provider read properties applied to all read operations.
entityProviderReadProperties.title: Entity Provider Read Properties

entityProviderWriteProperties.description: Custom entity provider write properties applied to create, update, patch, batch and merge operations. For instance users can skip the Json object wrapper or enable content only mode when sending request data. A service URI set in the properties will always be overwritten by the serviceUri configuration parameter. Please consider to using the serviceUri configuration parameter instead of setting the respective write property here.
entityProviderWriteProperties.title: Entity Provider Write Properties

filterAlreadySeen.description: Set this to true to filter out results that have already been communicated by this component.
filterAlreadySeen.title: Filter Already Seen

httpHeaders.description: Custom HTTP headers to inject into every request, this could include OAuth tokens, etc.

serviceUri.title: Service Uri

socketTimeout.description: HTTP request timeout in milliseconds, defaults to 30,000 (30 seconds)

sendEmptyMessageWhenIdle.description: If the polling consumer did not poll any files, you can enable this option to send an empty message (no body) instead.

splitResult.description: For endpoints that return an array or collection, a consumer endpoint will map every element to distinct messages, unless splitResult is set to false.

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

paho.title: Paho
paho.description: Communicate with MQTT message brokers using Eclipse Paho MQTT Client.

automaticReconnect.description: Sets whether the client will automatically attempt to reconnect to the server if the connection is lost. If set to false, the client will not attempt to automatically reconnect to the server in the event that the connection is lost. If set to true, in the event that the connection is lost, the client will attempt to reconnect to the server. It will initially wait 1 second before it attempts to reconnect, for every failed reconnect attempt, the delay will double until it is at 2 minutes at which point the delay will stay at 2 minutes.
automaticReconnect.title: Automatic Reconnect

brokerUrl.description: The URL of the MQTT broker.
brokerUrl.title: Broker Url

cleanSession.description: Sets whether the client and server should remember state across restarts and reconnects. If set to false both the client and server will maintain state across restarts of the client, the server and the connection. As state is maintained: Message delivery will be reliable meeting the specified QOS even if the client, server or connection are restarted. The server will treat a subscription as durable. If set to true the client and server will not maintain state across restarts of the client, the server or the connection. This means Message delivery to the specified QOS cannot be maintained if the client, server or connection are restarted The server will treat a subscription as non-durable
cleanSession.title: Clean Session

clientId.description: MQTT client identifier. The identifier must be unique.
clientId.title: Client Id

connectionTimeout.description: Sets the connection timeout value. This value, measured in seconds, defines the maximum time interval the client will wait for the network connection to the MQTT server to be established. The default timeout is 30 seconds. A value of 0 disables timeout processing meaning the client will wait until the network connection is made successfully or fails.
connectionTimeout.title: Connection Timeout

filePersistenceDirectory.description: Base directory used by file persistence. Will by default use user directory.
filePersistenceDirectory.title: File Persistence Directory

keepAliveInterval.description: Sets the keep alive interval. This value, measured in seconds, defines the maximum time interval between messages sent or received. It enables the client to detect if the server is no longer available, without having to wait for the TCP/IP timeout. The client will ensure that at least one message travels across the network within each keep alive period. In the absence of a data-related message during the time period, the client sends a very small ping message, which the server will acknowledge. A value of 0 disables keepalive processing in the client. The default value is 60 seconds
keepAliveInterval.title: Keep Alive Interval

maxInflight.description: Sets the max inflight. please increase this value in a high traffic environment. The default value is 10
maxInflight.title: Max Inflight

maxReconnectDelay.description: Get the maximum time (in millis) to wait between reconnects
maxReconnectDelay.title: Max Reconnect Delay

mqttVersion.description: Sets the MQTT version. The default action is to connect with version 3.1.1, and to fall back to 3.1 if that fails. Version 3.1.1 or 3.1 can be selected specifically, with no fall back, by using the MQTT_VERSION_3_1_1 or MQTT_VERSION_3_1 options respectively.
mqttVersion.title: Mqtt Version

persistence.description: Client persistence to be used - memory or file.
persistence.title: Persistence

serverURIs.description: Set a list of one or more serverURIs the client may connect to. Multiple servers can be separated by comma. Each serverURI specifies the address of a server that the client may connect to. Two types of connection are supported tcp:// for a TCP connection and ssl:// for a TCP connection secured by SSL/TLS. For example: tcp://localhost:1883 ssl://localhost:8883 If the port is not specified, it will default to 1883 for tcp:// URIs, and 8883 for ssl:// URIs. If serverURIs is set then it overrides the serverURI parameter passed in on the constructor of the MQTT client. When an attempt to connect is initiated the client will start with the first serverURI in the list and work through the list until a connection is established with a server. If a connection cannot be made to any of the servers then the connect attempt fails. Specifying a list of servers that a client may connect to has several uses: High Availability and reliable message delivery Some MQTT servers support a high availability feature where two or more equal MQTT servers share state. An MQTT client can connect to any of the equal servers and be assured that messages are reliably delivered and durable subscriptions are maintained no matter which server the client connects to. The cleansession flag must be set to false if durable subscriptions and/or reliable message delivery is required. Hunt List A set of servers may be specified that are not equal (as in the high availability option). As no state is shared across the servers reliable message delivery and durable subscriptions are not valid. The cleansession flag must be set to true if the hunt list mode is used
serverURIs.title: Server URIs

willPayload.description: Sets the Last Will and Testament (LWT) for the connection. In the event that this client unexpectedly loses its connection to the server, the server will publish a message to itself using the supplied details. Sets the message for the LWT.
willPayload.title: Will Payload

willQos.description: Sets the Last Will and Testament (LWT) for the connection. In the event that this client unexpectedly loses its connection to the server, the server will publish a message to itself using the supplied details. Sets the quality of service to publish the message at (0, 1 or 2).
willQos.title: Will Qos

willRetained.description: Sets the Last Will and Testament (LWT) for the connection. In the event that this client unexpectedly loses its connection to the server, the server will publish a message to itself using the supplied details. Sets whether or not the message should be retained.
willRetained.title: Will Retained

willTopic.description: Sets the Last Will and Testament (LWT) for the connection. In the event that this client unexpectedly loses its connection to the server, the server will publish a message to itself using the supplied details. Sets the topic that the willPayload will be published to.
willTopic.title: Will Topic

bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
bridgeErrorHandler.title: Bridge Error Handler

exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.
exceptionHandler.title: Exception Handler

exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.
exchangePattern.title: Exchange Pattern

lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.
lazyStartProducer.title: Lazy Start Producer

client.description: To use an existing mqtt client
client.title: Client

customWebSocketHeaders.description: Sets the Custom WebSocket Headers for the WebSocket Connection.
customWebSocketHeaders.title: Custom Web Socket Headers

executorServiceTimeout.description: Set the time in seconds that the executor service should wait when terminating before forcefully terminating. It is not recommended to change this value unless you are absolutely sure that you need to.
executorServiceTimeout.title: Executor Service Timeout

httpsHostnameVerificationEnabled.description: Whether SSL HostnameVerifier is enabled or not. The default value is true.
httpsHostnameVerificationEnabled.title: Https Hostname Verification Enabled

password.description: Password to be used for authentication against the MQTT broker
password.title: Password

socketFactory.description: Sets the SocketFactory to use. This allows an application to apply its own policies around the creation of network sockets. If using an SSL connection, an SSLSocketFactory can be used to supply application-specific security settings.
socketFactory.title: Socket Factory

sslClientProps.description: Sets the SSL properties for the connection. Note that these properties are only valid if an implementation of the Java Secure Socket Extensions (JSSE) is available. These properties are not used if a custom SocketFactory has been set. The following properties can be used: com.ibm.ssl.protocol One of: SSL, SSLv3, TLS, TLSv1, SSL_TLS. com.ibm.ssl.contextProvider Underlying JSSE provider. For example IBMJSSE2 or SunJSSE com.ibm.ssl.keyStore The name of the file that contains the KeyStore object that you want the KeyManager to use. For example /mydir/etc/key.p12 com.ibm.ssl.keyStorePassword The password for the KeyStore object that you want the KeyManager to use. The password can either be in plain-text, or may be obfuscated using the static method: com.ibm.micro.security.Password.obfuscate(char password). This obfuscates the password using a simple and insecure XOR and Base64 encoding mechanism. Note that this is only a simple scrambler to obfuscate clear-text passwords. com.ibm.ssl.keyStoreType Type of key store, for example PKCS12, JKS, or JCEKS. com.ibm.ssl.keyStoreProvider Key store provider, for example IBMJCE or IBMJCEFIPS. com.ibm.ssl.trustStore The name of the file that contains the KeyStore object that you want the TrustManager to use. com.ibm.ssl.trustStorePassword The password for the TrustStore object that you want the TrustManager to use. The password can either be in plain-text, or may be obfuscated using the static method: com.ibm.micro.security.Password.obfuscate(char password). This obfuscates the password using a simple and insecure XOR and Base64 encoding mechanism. Note that this is only a simple scrambler to obfuscate clear-text passwords. com.ibm.ssl.trustStoreType The type of KeyStore object that you want the default TrustManager to use. Same possible values as keyStoreType. com.ibm.ssl.trustStoreProvider Trust store provider, for example IBMJCE or IBMJCEFIPS. com.ibm.ssl.enabledCipherSuites A list of which ciphers are enabled. Values are dependent on the provider, for example: SSL_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA;SSL_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA. com.ibm.ssl.keyManager Sets the algorithm that will be used to instantiate a KeyManagerFactory object instead of using the default algorithm available in the platform. Example values: IbmX509 or IBMJ9X509. com.ibm.ssl.trustManager Sets the algorithm that will be used to instantiate a TrustManagerFactory object instead of using the default algorithm available in the platform. Example values: PKIX or IBMJ9X509.
sslClientProps.title: Ssl Client Props

sslHostnameVerifier.description: Sets the HostnameVerifier for the SSL connection. Note that it will be used after handshake on a connection and you should do actions by yourself when hostname is verified error. There is no default HostnameVerifier
sslHostnameVerifier.title: Ssl Hostname Verifier

userName.description: Username to be used for authentication against the MQTT broker
userName.title: User Name

receiveMaximum.description: Sets the Receive Maximum. This value represents the limit of QoS 1 and QoS 2 publications that the client is willing to process concurrently. There is no mechanism to limit the number of QoS 0 publications that the Server might try to send. The default value is 65535
receiveMaximum.title: Receive Maximum

Each serverURI specifies the address of a server that the client may connect to. Two types of connection are supported tcp:// for a TCP connection and ssl:// for a TCP connection secured by SSL/TLS. For example: tcp://localhost:1883 ssl://localhost:8883 If the port is not specified, it will default to 1883 for tcp:// URIs, and 8883 for ssl:// URIs. If serverURIs is set then it overrides the serverURI parameter passed in on the constructor of the MQTT client. Hunt List A set of servers may be specified that are not equal (as in the high availability option). serverURIs.title: Server URIs

sessionExpiryInterval.description: Sets the Session Expiry Interval. This value, measured in seconds, defines the maximum time that the broker will maintain the session for once the client disconnects. Clients should only connect with a long Session Expiry interval if they intend to connect to the server at some later point in time. By default this value is -1 and so will not be sent, in this case, the session will not expire. If a 0 is sent, the session will end immediately once the Network Connection is closed. When the client has determined that it has no longer any use for the session, it should disconnect with a Session Expiry Interval set to 0.
sessionExpiryInterval.title: Session Expiry Interval

willMqttProperties.description: Sets the Last Will and Testament (LWT) for the connection. In the event that this client unexpectedly loses its connection to the server, the server will publish a message to itself using the supplied details. The MQTT properties set for the message.
